dph of rules wrote:

> Here's something horrible.  You summon a defense and your clerics run
> away to fight other enemies.  Then, a cleric yells for help.  Whose
> fault is it that the cleric dies?  Or another thing.  I summon a
> defense, but my cleric insists on doing his own thing or worse yet,
> becomes frozen stiff.  I swear clerics need to be re-programmed to be
> more team players than individuals.  If enemy clerics would
> consentrate on protecting others, I would swear I would never be able
> to win.
>

A lot of the characters are like that, they will engage the nearest enemy
unless
called on.  Instead of summoning defense, I find that my players tend to
tune to
the consistency of constantly shouting YO as long as you're moving
somewhere,
much better than summoned defense.


> I am trying to play through gladiator with 2 clerics and 2 mages.
> I'll let one become an archmage.  Smaller teams mean everyone gets
> upgrades quicker but have problems taking on large numbers at a time.
>  Larger teams means slower upgrades but fewer problems taking on
> large
> numbers at a time.  When I finish through with 2 clerics and 2 mages,
> I may try a team of 2 clerics, 2 mages, and 2 elves.

Completely true.  If you're fighting the Westwood elves for example, that
level can become nearly overwhelming with a small team like you or I seem
to be playing (I play 1 archmage and two clerics). When my friend
introduced me to this game (and I ended up registering within a few days)
we would hire plenty of virtual cannon fodder, treating soldiers more like
a temporary bonus for the level while we kept two main characters going.
I think I was a druid and he was a cleric.

>
> My own problem with mages is that they frequently run out of magic
> power when engaging the enemy.  I really think that a mage should be
> treated as a spy unless the mage has a super high power level.
> Speaking of which, is there a intelligence level high enough for a
> mage to continously teleport without running out of magic power?

Mages are extremely hard to level at the lower levels, and in some cases
even harder to keep alive and well.  If you are constantly "Yo"'ing,
your computer-controlled mages will probably not teleport away, unless
they get into some kind of conflict.

In answer to your question: Yes, there is an intelligence level whereby
mages can constantly teleport without ever running out of magical power.
Similarly, there is an intelligence level where they can never run out of
magical power while shooting their energy balls, but I think this is hella
high for the archmage, because of the amount of magical power that
their energy balls take off.  The mage has an easier time attaining this
intelligence level.


> Does anyone know how to use a thief effectively?  I discovered that
> theives are usually more trouble than their worth because of a
> tendacy
> to create bombs if they are not busy.

Thieves are among my favorite characters -- partially because of their
speed,
and partially because of their priceless taunt skill.  The problem with them
is
that, like clerics, they aren't great if the computer is controlling them.
They
are very good if you are controlling them and no how forever.  Here's one
strategy I like to use with early-on thieves (works insanely well in the
slime
level).

Drop a bomb, or a cluster of bombs -- however many your intelligence allows
you to make.  Throw a few knives at a nearby foe and wait for him to attack
you.  Run backwards, standing past the bombs, and wait for your foe to walk
over them.  If your foe is fast, you have to use the circle and strike
method,
which is a tad more difficult. :

Say you are fighting a skeleton, or a group of them. They aren't very hardy,
but
they certainly are fast -- faster than your thief.  You aren't having a lot
of luck
dropping bombs and luring them into your trap, so you have to change your
strategy.  Bring some enemies to your cluster of bombs and begin circling
them,
keeping the circle small enough so that the enemy will stay on the bombs,
turning occasionally to toss a bone at you.  Eventually, the bombs will go
off
and harm your enemy.

---

This is the strategy that has made thieves one of the more useful classes
for me.
That and their ability to go invisible whenever you so please (so long as
you've
got the intelligence to stay in those shadows) as well as a poison cloud
that can
be used similarly to bombs, except it does perpetual damage.  If you're used
to
using a thief, and practice a lot, you can send him or her into the enemy's
reproduction zones (with towers, bone piles, skeleton tents and whatnot) and

bomb the bajeebers out of those guys, helping your team out considerably.

Because of their speed, you can also leave thieves alone if you're fighting
slower enemies like elves.
